newsitem.title: FRANCE: Total sees no hindrance to Iraq, Iran oil deals.
newsitem.headline: Total sees no hindrance to Iraq, Iran oil deals.

text.p: Total SA chairman Thierry Desmarest has said he sees no hindrance to doing deals with Iraq or Iran despite political opposition from the United States.

Total has agreed with Iraq to buy crude oil under the terms of the United Nations oil-for-food deal and is seeking, once sanctions are lifted in full, to develop the giant Nahr Umar field which could have a capacity of 500,000 barrels per day.

"We believe that nothing is preventing us from signing with Iraq under the condition that the contract does not take effect until after the U.N. sanctions have been lifted," Desmarest told a news conference on the company's results on Wednesday.
In Iran, Total signed a contract with the government in June 1995 for a $600 million contract to develop the Sirri A and E offshore oil fields, a deal which has upset the United States.
In August last year, President Clinton signed the so-called D'Amato bill that seeks to punish foreign firms investing in such countries as Iran or Libya.

"As we have said before. The D'Amato bill is not retroactive and does not affect our deal with Iran. As far as any possible future deals are concerned, Europe is contesting the extraterritorial application of the bill," Desmarest said.
